entry.title: Lecture 6d, Truth at a Context and an Index

div.p: This video solves the problem raised in the previous video and makes the distinction between the context parameter and the index.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 6d, Truth at a Context and an Index
media:group.media:description: This video solves the problem raised in the previous video and makes the distinction between the context parameter and the index.

div.p: This video outlines why MacFarlane takes relativism to be superior to both contextualism and sensitive invariantism.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 6f, The Argument for Relativism
media:group.media:description: This video outlines why MacFarlane takes relativism to be superior to both contextualism and sensitive invariantism.

div.p: This video lays out the relativist view of knowledge and explains how relative truth hooks up to assertion and rejection.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 6e, Relativism about Knowledge
media:group.media:description: This video lays out the relativist view of knowledge and explains how relative truth hooks up to assertion and rejection.

div.p: This video lays out the first half of the argument that truth needs to be relativised to multiple parameters.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 6c, Relativising Truth
media:group.media:description: This video lays out the first half of the argument that truth needs to be relativised to multiple parameters.

entry.title: Lecture 6b, Problems for Contextualism and Invariantism

div.p: This video lays out the problems MacFarlane uses to motivate relativism about knowledge.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 6b, Problems for Contextualism and Invariantism
media:group.media:description: This video lays out the problems MacFarlane uses to motivate relativism about knowledge.

entry.title: Lecture 5d, The Invariantist Solution to the Lottery Puzzle

div.p: In this video, we see how Hawthorne applies invariantism to the lottery puzzle.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 5d, The Invariantist Solution to the Lottery Puzzle
media:group.media:description: In this video, we see how Hawthorne applies invariantism to the lottery puzzle.

div.p: This video outlines some problems for the invariantist solution to the lottery puzzle.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 5e, Problems for Invariantism
media:group.media:description: This video outlines some problems for the invariantist solution to the lottery puzzle.

div.p: This video lays out in depth the Moderate Sensitive Invariantist approach, focusing on the different predictions they make about 3rd person knowledge ascriptions.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 5c, Moderate Sensitive Invariantism
media:group.media:description: This video lays out in depth the Moderate Sensitive Invariantist approach, focusing on the different predictions they make about 3rd person knowledge ascriptions.

div.p: This is the second component of Lecture 2, which introduces you to the idea of a counterfactual and outlines a simple theory of what counterfactuals mean.

div.p: This is the first part of Lecture 2, which recaps the simple skeptical argument we read in Moore and contrasts two big picture theories of knowledge.

div.p: This is the final component of the lecture, which introduces the possible worlds theory of knowledge and belief.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 1d, Knowledge and Belief
media:group.media:description: This is the final component of the lecture, which introduces the possible worlds theory of knowledge and belief.

div.p: This is the third component of the lecture, which discusses logical operations on propositions, the notions of possibility and necessity, and entailment.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 1c, More on Propositions
media:group.media:description: This is the third component of the lecture, which discusses logical operations on propositions, the notions of possibility and necessity, and entailment.

div.p: This is the second component of the lecture, which introduces the notion of a possible world and outlines the possible worlds theory of propositions.

media:group.media:title: Lecture 1b, Possible Worlds
media:group.media:description: This is the second component of the lecture, which introduces the notion of a possible world and outlines the possible worlds theory of propositions.
